customer_addr:
9008 Front Beach Road
Panama City Beach, FL 32407

citations.narrative:
The inspector went into the facility as a paying guest and spent time at the rabbit enclosure just prior to announcing for
the inspection process. At this time, there was no attendant at the rabbit enclosure, and she was able to interact and have
direct contact with the rabbits. For the safety of the animals, a responsible and knowledgeable employee or attendant
must be present at all times during periods of public contact.
Correct by: October 29, 2024

There is a drain cover in the ring tail lemur enclosure on the ground that has a hole cut to fit a pvc pipe. The pipe no
longer fits securely in the opening and there is now a large hole in the cover in which the lemurs could subsequently put
their arm or feet in and potentially be injured. This drain cover needs to be addressed so the floor is constructed in a
manner that protects the animals from injuring themselves.
Correct by: Nov 04, 2024

A section of the fencing located behind the aardwolf enclosure an approximate nine inch-tall gap between the fence and
the ground; large enough for animals to pass through.
Inadequate perimeter fencing can allow for access of unauthorized persons and other animals and fail to act as
secondary containment for the animals in the facility. This could lead to injury, escape, or death of the animal.
All outdoor housing must be enclosed by a perimeter fence. The perimeter fence must protect the animals in the facility by
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the
facility. The perimeter fence must also function as secondary containment for the animals housed within.
Correct by: Nov 04, 2024

The metal chute feeders in the hyena and lion building need to be cleaned. There is an excessive build up of old pieces of
meat in the chute and on the lid that need to be cleaned. In addition, sections of the metal feeder are rusted and rusted
areas can flake off into the food passing down the chute to the animals. Food receptacles shall be always kept clean and
sanitary for the health of the animals.
Correct by: Oct 30, 2024

Pest control around the hyena and lion building must be addressed. Many small, tan to black cockroaches were observed
scurrying along the back side of the lion holding pens and feeders. An effective program to mitigate and control the
number of pests in this building needs to be implemented for the health of the animals.
Correct by: November 11, 2024

In the budgie aviary, there is a metal support beam that is rusted and degraded to the point that there are holes and sharp
points in the metal. This section of metal must be replaced for the safety of the birds and to keep the enclosure in good
repair.
Correct by: Nov 11, 2024

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The physical environment for multiple bird species including knobbed hornbill, southern ground hornbill, and the macaws
had either no or very limited enrichment through materials or activities. There was no additional cage complexity provided,
nor objects to manipulate or any use of foraging or task-oriented feeding methods. The documented enrichment plan
stated “Enrichment should be provided to all aves at regular intervals.” The plan called for “regular rotation” of exhibit
furniture, food items, scents and toys. There is no evidence that the plan documented is being followed. The physical
environment in primary enclosures must be enriched by materials or activities at an appropriate frequency to promote
needs the psychological welfare of the birds.
Correct by October 31, 2024

The pool for 24 lesser flamingo and 6 chilean flamingo has water that is green and opaque. Currently there are two
animals under treatment for bumblefoot. The facility states it is currently drained and cleaned every two weeks. The
frequency of cleaning and the condition of the water does not suggest adequate water quality and this may create a
disease hazard to the birds. Particulate animal and food waste, trash, or debris that enters the pool or other aquatic area
must be removed as often as necessary to maintain the required water quality and minimize health hazards to the birds.
Correct by: October 30, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
ANDREA D AMBROSIO, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The inspector went into the facility as a paying guest and spent time at the rabbit enclosure just prior to announcing for 
the inspection process. At this time, there was no attendant at the rabbit enclosure, and she was able to interact and have 
direct contact with the rabbits. For the safety of the animals, a responsible and knowledgeable employee or attendant 
must be present at all times during periods of public contact. 
Correct by: October 29, 2024 
3.80(a)(2)(x) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There is a drain cover in the ring tail lemur enclosure on the ground that has a hole cut to fit a pvc pipe. The pipe no 
longer fits securely in the opening and there is now a large hole in the cover in which the lemurs could subsequently put 
their arm or feet in and potentially be injured. This drain cover needs to be addressed so the floor is constructed in a 
manner that protects the animals from injuring themselves.  
Correct by: Nov 04, 2024 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
A section of the fencing located behind the aardwolf enclosure an approximate nine inch-tall gap between the fence and 
the ground; large enough for animals to pass through.  
 
Inadequate perimeter fencing can allow for access of unauthorized persons and other animals and fail to act as 
secondary containment for the animals in the facility. This could lead to injury, escape, or death of the animal. 
 
All outdoor housing must be enclosed by a perimeter fence. The perimeter fence must protect the animals in the facility by 
restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the 
facility. The perimeter fence must also function as secondary containment for the animals housed within. 
Correct by: Nov 04, 2024

3.129(b) 
   
Feeding. 
The metal chute feeders in the hyena and lion building need to be cleaned. There is an excessive build up of old pieces of 
meat in the chute and on the lid that need to be cleaned. In addition, sections of the metal feeder are rusted and rusted 
areas can flake off into the food passing down the chute to the animals. Food receptacles shall be always kept clean and 
sanitary for the health of the animals.  
Correct by: Oct 30, 2024 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
Pest control around the hyena and lion building must be addressed. Many small, tan to black cockroaches were observed 
scurrying along the back side of the lion holding pens and feeders. An effective program to mitigate and control the 
number of pests in this building needs to be implemented for the health of the animals. 
 
Correct by: November 11, 2024 
3.150(c)(2) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In the budgie aviary, there is a metal support beam that is rusted and degraded to the point that there are holes and sharp 
points in the metal. This section of metal must be replaced for the safety of the birds and to keep the enclosure in good 
repair.  
Correct by: Nov 11, 2024 
3.154(b) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The physical environment for multiple bird species including knobbed hornbill, southern ground hornbill, and the macaws 
had either no or very limited enrichment through materials or activities. There was no additional cage complexity provided, 
nor objects to manipulate or any use of foraging or task-oriented feeding methods. The documented enrichment plan 
stated “Enrichment should be provided to all aves at regular intervals.” The plan called for “regular rotation” of exhibit 
furniture, food items, scents and toys. There is no evidence that the plan documented is being followed. The physical 
environment in primary enclosures must be enriched by materials or activities at an appropriate frequency to promote 
needs the psychological welfare of the birds. 
 
Correct by October 31, 2024 
3.157(a)(1) 
   
Water quality. 
The pool for 24 lesser flamingo and 6 chilean flamingo has water that is green and opaque. Currently there are two 
animals under treatment for bumblefoot. The facility states it is currently drained and cleaned every two weeks. The

frequency of cleaning and the condition of the water does not suggest adequate water quality and this may create a 
disease hazard to the birds. Particulate animal and food waste, trash, or debris that enters the pool or other aquatic area 
must be removed as often as necessary to maintain the required water quality and minimize health hazards to the birds. 
Correct by: October 30, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
